moves.1. e4: This is a game from the first round of the 37th GK tournament.   This is, I think, a good lesson in early development.  Let me know what you think.
moves.1... d5 2. exd5 Qxd5: The Scandinavian or centre-counter attack.  I don't mind playing against this variation as white, since I think that developing the black Queen at this early stage allows white some initiative.
moves.3. Nc3 Qa5 4. d4 c6 5. Bd2 Qd8 6. Nf3: Already, white is way ahead of black in piece development.
moves.6... Bg4 7. h3: Offering the D pawn for extra development and initiative...
moves.9. O-O-O Qb6 10. Bc4: Black is way off the pace here - he really needs some pieces to join his queen on the open board!
moves.10... Nf6 11. Bg5 Nbd7 12. Bxf7+: A nice way to win back the pawn and expose the black King
moves.12... Kxf7 13. Rxd7: The point of my temporary bishop sacrifice.  The rook cannot be recaptured by the black Knight as it is pinned.
moves.13... h6: A mistake as this allows white's Queen into the attack
moves.15... Kg7 16. Re1: Threatening a nice sacrifice with Rxe7 , bxe7, Rxe7  leading to mate on f7 or g6.
moves.17. Re4: curtains!  White threatens either Rg4 , but in any event the black queen must now move from a dark square, allowing the capture on e7 and mate.  At this point, my opponent graciously resigned.
